conclusion: The suitcase has a mass of 15 kg and is pulled with an oblique upward force of 90 N to achieve uniform motion on a horizontal surface. The angle between the pull and the horizontal is θ, and the coefficient of friction is μ. Gravitational acceleration is g = 10 m/s², and sin 37° = 0.6.
The image shows a suitcase with wheels that can be pushed or pulled on the ground.

premise: The suitcase has a mass of 15 kg, and gravitational acceleration is g = 10 m/s².
conclusion: The weight of the suitcase is W = mg = 15 × 10 = 150 N.
The forces acting on the suitcase include: weight (W), normal force (N), tension in the pull (F = 90 N), and frictional force (f = μN).

premise: The pull force F = 90 N acts at an angle θ to the horizontal.
conclusion: The pull force can be resolved into horizontal and vertical components: F cos θ (horizontal) and F sin θ (vertical).

premise: The suitcase is in equilibrium in the vertical direction.
conclusion: The normal force N and the vertical component of the pull balance the weight: N + F sin θ = W, so N = W - F sin θ.

premise: The suitcase is in equilibrium in the horizontal direction.
conclusion: The horizontal component of the pull balances the frictional force: F cos θ = μN.

premise: N = W - F sin θ and F cos θ = μN.
conclusion: Substituting N into the horizontal equilibrium equation: F cos θ = μ(W - F sin θ).

premise: F cos θ = μ(W - F sin θ).
conclusion: Rearranging: F cos θ + μF sin θ = μW.

premise: F cos θ + μF sin θ = μW.
conclusion: Dividing through by W: μ = (F/W)(cos θ + μ sin θ).

premise: The minimum pull occurs when the component of the pull in the horizontal direction equals the frictional force.

conclusion: Rearranging: 90 cos θ + 90 μ sin θ = 150 μ.

premise: 90 cos θ + 90 μ sin θ = 150 μ.
conclusion: Dividing through by 150: (3/5)(cos θ + μ sin θ) = μ.
This equation relates μ and θ. To solve, we use the fact that the minimum pull occurs when the angle θ minimizes the pull force.
